channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chen Zhonglin on ‘Picking Quarrels’ Online
item.description: Mr. Chen, a law professor at Chongqing University, discussed the meaning of “rule of law” and the uses and abuses of the charge of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.”
item.dc:creator: ADAM WU
item.media:description: Chen Zhonglin, law professor at Chongqing University.

item.title: Chinese Shares Tumble Again
item.description: The main Shanghai index slid 8.5 percent, it’s biggest one-day decline in eight years, abruptly ending a nearly three-week lull in the market rout.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The plunge in China's stock market was displayed on Monday at a brokerage house in Hangzhou.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Advocates, and a Monk, Oppose Beijing’s Winter Olympics Bid
item.description: Opponents of the effort by China are citing a widening crackdown on rights defense lawyers, political activists and ethnic minorities.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN and ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Golog Jigme, an exiled Tibetan monk, has urged that Beijing not be awarded the 2022 Winter Games.

item.title: At Least 20 Are Killed in Attack at Afghan Wedding Party
item.description: The authorities suspected that a local dispute had caused the shooting in a village in northern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Turkey and U.S. Plan to Create Syria ‘Safe Zone’ Free of ISIS
item.description: American warplanes, Turkish forces and anti-ISIS rebels within Syria would join to clear a section along the border, creating what the Turks call a “safe zone” for refugees.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey. Turkey and the United States agreed on a plan that would create what officials are calling an Islamic State-free zone, which the Turks say could also be a “safe zone” for displaced Syrians.

item.title: Observatory: Farming Had an Earlier Start, a Study Says
item.description: Farming may have originated 23,000 years ago, thousands of years earlier than previously thought, according to seeds researchers found at an ancient site.
item.dc:creator: SINDYA N. BHANOO

item.title: Obama, in Ethiopia, Addresses South Sudan Conflict
item.description: He convened a meeting to try to forge peace in the new country, the birth of which four years ago was the capstone of his Africa policy.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: President Obama in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Monday, where he will convene a meeting to try to forge a peace in South Sudan.

item.title: Inquiry Into Litvinenko Poisoning Is Delayed After Russian Fails to Testify
item.description: A lawyer said the man was “not in a position to give oral evidence” because he felt bound by confidentiality agreements related to a separate, Russian inquiry into the ex-K.G.B. officer’s death.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Dmitri V. Kovtun in Moscow in April.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Hissène Habré, a Trial by Refusal
item.description: The former president of Chad scuttled his trial for mass crimes by turning the principles of human rights defenders against them.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THIERRY CRUVELLIER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How the Greek Deal Could Destroy the Euro
item.description: By treating Grexit as a viable option, Europe has made a future French, or even German, exit more likely.
item.dc:creator: SHAHIN VALLÉE

item.title: Palestinian, 18, Dies While Trying to Evade Arrest, Israeli Police Say
item.description: The Israeli police spokesman, Micky Rosenfeld, said the man had been shot as he ran across rooftops in the Kalandia refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Mourners buried Mohammad Atta Lafi Abu Latifa in Kalandia refugee camp, near the West Bank city of Ramallah, on Monday.

item.title: Gunmen in India Kill at Least 5 in Attack on Bus and Police Station
item.description: The attackers, who were said to be dressed in Indian Army uniforms, stormed the police station after opening fire on an intercity bus in Punjab, the police said.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: British Lord Resigns Posts in Scandal Over Drugs
item.description: John Sewel, who was a deputy speaker of the House of Lords, faced a police investigation into accusations that he had taken cocaine with two prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: John Sewel, a member of the House of Lords.

item.title: Drugged, Kidnapped and Enslaved
item.description: In 2011, Asorasak Thamma was kidnapped in Thailand and enslaved on a fishing boat. Interviewed last year, he had not been home since.

item.title: The Outlaw Ocean: ‘Sea Slaves’: The Human Misery That Feeds Pets and Livestock
item.description: Men who have fled servitude on fishing boats recount beatings and worse as nets are cast for the catch that will become pet food and livestock feed.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cambodian migrants hauled in the nets on a fishing boat in the South China Sea. A labor shortage in the Thai fishing industry is primarily filled by using migrants, mostly from Cambodia and Myanmar.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Just Close Bases at Home, Close Them Overseas
item.description: U.S. military facilities abroad have overstayed their welcome. Shutting them will save money, and possibly lives.
item.dc:creator: DAVID VINE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Doctors, Under Strain and Threat, Call for Support in Video
item.description: A new compilation of interviews with Chinese doctors seeks to shed light on the daily burdens and joys of a profession struggling with long hours, low pay and the threat of violence from patients and their families.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Hospital workers protested against attacks on medical personnel outside No. 1 People's Hospital in Wenling, Zhejiang Province, on Oct. 28, 2013, after a man stabbed three doctors, killing one. The sign on the left says: "Restore my dignity."

item.title: Obama Delivers Tough-Love Message to End Kenya Trip
item.description: In a speech on Sunday, President Obama challenged the land of his father to end corruption, overcome ethnic divisions and stop discrimination against women.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya with President Obama on Sunday at the end of the two-day trip. Mr. Obama said the country needed to overcome ethnic divisions and end discrimination.

item.title: Obama’s Visit to Ethiopia Promises Little for Human Rights Activists
item.description: During President Obama’s visit to the country, the first by a sitting American president, issues like investment and terrorism are expected to take precedence.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.media:description: A billboard in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia's capital, on Sunday, the day President Obama arrived there.

item.title: Memo From China: China Uses ‘Picking Quarrels’ Charge to Cast a Wider Net Online
item.description: In its growing Internet crackdown, Beijing has turned to an old ban on “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” once limited to physical acts like handing out fliers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong demonstrated the detention of Pu Zhiqiang, a civil rights lawyer from Beijing charged with "picking quarrels."
